title: AHA Scientific Statement 2023: Diagnosis, Workup, and Risk Reduction of TIA in the Emergency Department

recommendations.text: Perform point-of-care glucose for all suspected TIA to rule out hypoglycemia; obtain CBC, chemistry panel, A1c, and lipid profile to define risk factors.
Use ECG, telemetry, and troponin for all TIA patients; consider prolonged rhythm monitoring (about 30 days) within 6 months when cardioembolic source is suspected.
Perform acute-phase vessel imaging in the ED regardless of ABCD2 score to guide management; CTA is preferred, with MRA as alternative when contrast is contraindicated.
TIA risk stratification scales help identify high-risk patients and guide disposition decisions.
Presumed symptomatic >50% extracranial or intracranial stenosis warrants hospital admission.
Acceptable disposition options include rapid ED TIA protocols with expedited referral to specialized clinics, 24-hour observation, or standard hospital admission.
Disposition should reflect short-term stroke risk, vessel imaging, timeliness of workup, rapid follow-up availability, and patient ability to return for evaluation.
Institutional and regional factors should guide disposition protocols for TIA patients.
Maximal medical therapy includes antithrombotic therapy plus BP, glucose, and lipid control with targets consistent with established guidelines.
ABCD2 can guide antithrombotic regimens; use risk profiles rather than scores alone.
Provide counseling for patients with substance use disorders alongside medical management.
Address social determinants of health to reduce disparities in TIA care and outcomes.
